dialogue_line_replacements.text: No, soy hijo único. Pero tengo montones de primos.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: No, I'm an only child. But I have tons of cousins.

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Somos cinco: mis padres, mi abuela, mi hermana y yo.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: There are five of us: my parents, my grandmother, my sister and me.

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: In Puerto Rico, family gatherings (reuniones familiares) are central to social life. Extended family — tíos, primos, abuelos — are often treated as immediate family and may live nearby or together.
cultural_notes_overrides.family_values: 'Compadrazgo' (godparent bonds) is deeply important in PR culture. Godparents (padrinos/madrinas) are chosen carefully and maintain close family-like relationships throughout life.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: You'll often hear 'nene/nena' for young children, 'viejo/vieja' affectionately for parents or spouse, and 'chamaco' for a kid. 'Mano' (short for hermano) is used casually between close friends like brothers.
